Morning Service

Welcome to Temperance & Tuning

Our church was founded on a single, unglamorous miracle: the ability to keep a room calm while a saxophone insists on being heard. Every hour, a fresh version of our staff slides behind the desk, the pulpit, the espresso machine, and the door. They look alike because we believe in continuity. They sound alike because they all hum in E-flat.

Today, we open The Subscription of Mild Inconvenience, a membership that turns the small hurdles of daily life into an organized ritual. We make you wait just long enough to remember what you're waiting for. We ask for signatures twice. We return your calls but always on the third ring.

Live jazz, always. The band never leaves. They rotate instruments, never chairs.

Lobby Bulletin

  • Forms 12-C and 12-C (amended) are now distinct.
  • The coat check now requires a coat.
  • Every Tuesday is Tuesday.
Signed, Steward Avery (West) — today’s Avery

Ambient Regulation

“The point is not to slow you down,” says Avery (East), “but to return you to the exquisite pace of waiting with purpose.”

Order of the Hour

8:05 Sanctuary check-in, greeted by three Averys, all nodding.
8:11 Band shifts to a slower register; you receive a number.
8:19 Number is called softly. You are asked to confirm your name.
8:22 Avery (South) returns with the stamp, but hesitates for sincerity.
8:29 The stamp is delivered. The band applauds with brushes.

Membership

The Subscription of Mild Inconvenience

Every tier includes a live jazz attendant, ceremonial delays, and direct access to whichever Avery is on duty. You are never left alone, only paused with intention.

Letter from Avery (Founding)

Dear Member,
The hardest part of the modern day is the silence between tasks. We have filled those silences with softly insistent drums and the faint rustle of paperwork. Our staff is one person so that your memory of us does not fracture. Our delays are a promise: you are still here. You are still worth the hold.

Avery (Founding), Keeper of the First Queue

“I stopped rushing.”

The band turned the floor into a tide. I waited for the stamp and I felt the room breathe with me. — Mara J., subscriber since March

“The Avery I met was the Avery I needed.”

There was a version of him behind every counter. Not once did I feel dismissed. They look the same, but the patience felt custom. — R. Holden

“The hold music is alive.”

I renewed just for the trumpet. The delay has become my favorite part. — Miko S.

Hover to unfold the choir ledger
Every Avery signs the same ledger in a different hand. Our choir is clerical. If you listen closely, the cymbals mark their shifts.

The Night Service

The room darkens as the final sax note lingers. Avery (Northwest) gathers the day’s forgotten pens and lines them up like candles. You are invited to stay for the after-hours hymn, where the delays grow sacred and the final signature is always yours.

Tonight’s closer: “Time Kept Softly” in 5/4. Doors remain open.
